Vocabulary.mean: When someone is afraid, they feel fear.

Vocabulary.example: The gate was locked, so Bill had to find a different entrance.

Vocabulary.mean: If something hardly happens, it almost does not happen at all.
Vocabulary.example: I hardly saw the concert since I had to leave early.

Vocabulary.mean: To intend to do something means to plan to do it.
Vocabulary.example: I intend to finish college in three years.

Vocabulary.mean: Laughter is the sound produced by laughing about something funny.
Vocabulary.example: Susan’s joke made her classmates burst into laughter.

Vocabulary.mean: A log is a thick piece of wood that is cut from a tree.
Vocabulary.example: The fire was too small, so we added another log to it.

Vocabulary.mean: The military is the armed forces of a country.
Vocabulary.example: I joined the military after I finished high school.

Vocabulary.mean: To obey means to follow what a law or a person says you must do.
Vocabulary.example: My little sister did not obey my mother. Now she is in trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: To secure something means to get it after a lot of effort.
Vocabulary.example: I was able to secure a good grade on my test after weeks of studying.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is steady, they are under control.
Vocabulary.example: The problem was hard but she remained steady and solved it.

Vocabulary.mean: To trust is to believe that someone is honest and will do what is right.
Vocabulary.example: I trust my friends; they don’t tell my secrets to other people.

Vocabulary.mean: To twist something is to wrap it around itself or another thing.
Vocabulary.example: She twisted the spaghetti around her fork.

Vocabulary.mean: Unless means if not or except when.
Vocabulary.example: Unless you clean your room, you cannot play with your friends.

Vocabulary.mean: A weapon is an object that can be used to hurt people.
Vocabulary.example: Swords have been used as weapons for thousands of years.

Vocabulary.mean: The chest is the front part of a person’s body under the neck.
Vocabulary.example: The water in the lake was as high as my chest.

Vocabulary.mean: If you have confidence about something, you are sure of it.
Vocabulary.example: I have confidence that I did well on the test.

Vocabulary.mean: A consequence is a result of a choice or action.
Vocabulary.example: Asa consequence of missing my bus, I had to find another way to work.

Vocabulary.mean: A disaster is a really bad thing that happens.
Vocabulary.example: When the car crashed, it was a disaster.

Vocabulary.mean: To disturb someone means to upset them.
Vocabulary.example: The loud noise disturbed me while I was working.

Vocabulary.mean: To estimate something means to make a guess about it.
Vocabulary.example: The boy estimated that he was one meter tall.

Vocabulary.mean: When you honor people or things, you show respect for them.
Vocabulary.example: I honor my science teacher by working hard in class.

Vocabulary.mean: To impress someone means to make that person proud.
Vocabulary.example: He was able to impress the girls with his new dance.

Vocabulary.mean: A marathon is a very long foot race just over 42 kilometers.
Vocabulary.example: I ran a marathon, and now my legs are tired.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is narrow, it is very thin.
Vocabulary.example: The bridge is too narrow for a car to drive over.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is pale, it does not have a bright color.
Vocabulary.example: The girl’s skin was very pale.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is rough, it is not even or smooth.
Vocabulary.example: The rough ground hurt my feet.

Vocabulary.mean: To satisfy someone means to make them happy.
Vocabulary.example: It will satisfy my teacher if I finish all my homework.

Vocabulary.mean: To scream means to make a loud noise with your mouth.
Vocabulary.example: The girl saw a spider and screamed.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is sensitive, they are easily hurt.
Vocabulary.example: My teeth are sensitive to cold things.

Vocabulary.mean: The shade is a dark area that something makes when it blocks the sun.
Vocabulary.example: It was hot outside, so the boy sat in the shade of a tree.

Vocabulary.mean: To supplement something is to add something else to it in a good way.
Vocabulary.example: He supplements his diet with fresh fruits.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone feels terror, they are scared.
Vocabulary.example: I felt a sense of terror when the tiger chased me.

Vocabulary.mean: A threat is something bad that might happen.
Vocabulary.example: Due to the dark clouds, there was a threat of a bad storm.

Vocabulary.mean: A victim is a person that had something bad happen to them.
Vocabulary.example: I was a victim of a robbery.

Vocabulary.mean: An ancestor is a family member from the past.
Vocabulary.example: My ancestors came from Germany.

Vocabulary.mean: An angle is the direction from which you look at something.
Vocabulary.example: The giraffe turned its head to see from another angle.

Vocabulary.mean: A boot is a heavy shoe that goes over your ankle.
Vocabulary.example: He wore boots so that his feet wouldn’t get wet.

Vocabulary.mean: A border is the edge of an area.
Vocabulary.example: The postcard had a pretty green border of pine needles.

Vocabulary.mean: To congratulate someone is to tell them that you are happy for them.
Vocabulary.example: Bill and Angela congratulated each other on a job well done.

Vocabulary.mean: A frame is a border for a picture or mirror.
Vocabulary.example: I have to get a frame for my friend’s picture.

Vocabulary.mean: Heaven is the place that some people believe people go when they die.
Vocabulary.example: When I die, I hope that I go to heaven.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is incredible, it is hard to believe they are true.
Vocabulary.example: I have an incredible story to tell you about my vacation.

Vocabulary.mean: A legend is a story from the past.
Vocabulary.example: There is a welllegend about a king and his queen.

Vocabulary.mean: To praise is to show that you like someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: The coach praised both athletes after a good practice.

Vocabulary.mean: To proceed is to go in a certain direction.
Vocabulary.example: My son and I proceeded to the beach so we could go fishing.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is pure, it is very clear and beautiful.
Vocabulary.example: The rose was pure. It had no dirt or imperfections.

Vocabulary.mean: A relative is a family member.
Vocabulary.example: My relatives came by to see the new baby.

Vocabulary.mean: If one is senior, they are the oldest or have been there the longest.
Vocabulary.example: Because he got his job first, Bob is the senior chef.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is silent, they make no sound.
Vocabulary.example: Since no one was home, the house was silent.

Vocabulary.mean: To sink into something is to slowly fall into it.
Vocabulary.example: The boat had a hole in it, and it sank into the ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is superior, they are better than another.
Vocabulary.example: I think cooking outdoors is superior to cooking indoors.

Vocabulary.mean: To surround something is to close in on it from all sides.
Vocabulary.example: We surrounded the suspect on all four sides.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is thick, it is wide and solid.
Vocabulary.example: The fog was so thick that I couldn’t see through it.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.
